section1.title: Understanding Insider Trading
section1.p1: Insider trading is the buying or selling of securities by individuals who have access to material, non-public information about the company. Under SEBI regulations, this practice is strictly prohibited and carries severe penalties.
section1.p2: The practice undermines market integrity by giving unfair advantages to those with privileged information, creating an uneven playing field for retail investors.
section1.p3: SEBI defines material information as any information that would likely influence an investor's decision to buy or sell securities.

insiders.title: Who are 'Insiders'?
list: Employees with access to material information

penalties.title: SEBI Penalties
penalties.description: Maximum penalty: ₹25 crores or 3 times the profit made, whichever is higher. Additional criminal prosecution possible with up to 10 years imprisonment.

primaryInsiders.title: Primary Insiders
primaryInsiders.description: Direct access to material non-public information through their role in the company.

secondaryInsiders.title: Secondary Insiders (Temporary)
secondaryInsiders.description: Gain temporary access to material information through professional relationships.

tippees.title: Tippees
tippees.description: Individuals who receive material information from insiders, directly or indirectly.

circularTrading.title: Circular Trading
circularTrading.description: Trading between related parties to create artificial volume and mislead investors about market activity.
circularTrading.mechanism: Entity A sells to Entity B, Entity B sells to Entity C, Entity C sells back to Entity A
circularTrading.penalties: ₹10 crores or 3 times profits + market ban

washTrading.title: Wash Trading
washTrading.description: Simultaneously or near-simultaneously buying and selling the same security to create misleading activity.
washTrading.mechanism: Trader places buy and sell orders for same quantity at similar prices
washTrading.penalties: ₹15 crores or 3 times profits + criminal charges

spoofing.title: Spoofing
spoofing.description: Placing large orders with intent to cancel them before execution to manipulate market prices.
spoofing.mechanism: Place large buy order to drive price up, then cancel and sell at higher price

frontRunning.title: Front Running
frontRunning.description: Trading securities based on advance knowledge of pending large orders from clients or institutions.
frontRunning.mechanism: Broker learns of large client order, trades for own account first, then executes client order

scenario1.case: A software engineer working for a company learns during a team meeting that their company will announce a major partnership next week. He immediately buys ₹50,000 worth of company stock.
scenario1.question: What are the potential legal consequences?
scenario1.correctAnswer: Serious insider trading violation with penalties up to ₹1.5 lakh or 3 times profit
scenario1.explanation: Any employee with material non-public information is considered an insider. SEBI penalties apply regardless of the trading amount.

scenario2.case: A mutual fund manager receives a tip from his college friend (who works at a listed company) about poor quarterly results. The manager sells fund holdings worth ₹10 crores before the results are announced.
scenario2.question: What violations occurred and what are the penalties?
scenario2.correctAnswer: Both violated - friend as tipper (₹25 crores penalty) and manager as tippee (₹30 crores + fund penalties)
scenario2.explanation: Both tipper and tippee are equally liable. The fund manager faces additional institutional penalties and license risks.

dlfCase.title: DLF Insider Trading Case (2007-2009)
dlfCase.description: SEBI found DLF promoters and connected entities guilty of insider trading before the company's IPO.
dlfCase.lesson: Promoter trading before material announcements is closely monitored

rajatGupta.title: Rajat Gupta McKinsey Case (2012)
rajatGupta.description: Former McKinsey CEO convicted of insider trading in US courts, also impacted Indian regulatory framework.
rajatGupta.lesson: Cross-border insider trading has international consequences

bankNifty.title: Bank Nifty Options Manipulation (2020)
bankNifty.description: Coordinated manipulation of Bank Nifty options expiry through circular trading.
bankNifty.penalty: ₹25 crores penalty + market ban for multiple entities
